-->

<html><head><title>.htaccess Tutorial - Part 1</title>
<!--Description and keywords generated by script--><meta name="description" content="Learn how to use the .htaccess file to password protect parts of your website, deny or allow IP addresses and redirect users. (Free Webmaster Help)">
<meta name="keywords" content="htaccess, .htaccess, htaces, htacces, htacess, password, protect, website, folder, directory, ban, ip, redirect, pages, website, without, meta, refresh, tutorial, example, code">
<!-- Standard Heading -->
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<script language="JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_swapImgRestore() { //v3.0
  var i,x,a=document.MM_sr; for(i=0;a&&i<a.length&&(x=a[i])&&x.oSrc;i++) x.src=x.oSrc;
}

function MM_preloadImages() { //v3.0
  var d=document; if(d.images){ if(!d.MM_p) d.MM_p=new Array();
    var i,j=d.MM_p.length,a=MM_preloadImages.arguments; for(i=0; i<a.length; i++)
    if (a[i].indexOf("#")!=0){ d.MM_p[j]=new Image; d.MM_p[j++].src=a[i];}}
}

function MM_findObj(n, d) { //v4.0
  var p,i,x;  if(!d) d=document; if((p=n.indexOf("?"))>0&&parent.frames.length) {
    d=parent.frames[n.substring(p+1)].document; n=n.substring(0,p);}
  if(!(x=d[n])&&d.all) x=d.all[n]; for (i=0;!x&&i<d.forms.length;i++) x=d.forms[i][n];
  for(i=0;!x&&d.layers&&i<d.layers.length;i++) x=MM_findObj(n,d.layers[i].document);
  if(!x && document.getElementById) x=document.getElementById(n); return x;
}

function MM_swapImage() { //v3.0
  var i,j=0,x,a=MM_swapImage.arguments; document.MM_sr=new Array; for(i=0;i<(a.length-2);i+=3)
   if ((x=MM_findObj(a[i]))!=null){document.MM_sr[j++]=x; if(!x.oSrc) x.oSrc=x.src; x.src=a[i+2];}
}
//-->
</script>

            			<!-- Page Title -->
                       <p align="center"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="5"><b><font color="#000099" size="6">
                       .htaccess Tutorial<br>
              <font size="4" color="#000000">Part 1 - Introduction</font></font></b></font></p>

              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><b>Part 1 - Introduction</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/htaccess/2">Part 2 - .htaccess Commands</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/htaccess/3">Part 3 - Password Protection</a></li></ul></font>

              <!-- Page Content -->
              <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">
              <div align="right" style="float:right">
<iframe src="http://rcm.amazon.com/e/cm?t=freewebmaster-20&o=1&p=14&l=st1&mode=books&search=htaccess&fc1=000000&lt1=&lc1=3366FF&bg1=FFFFFF&f=ifr" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="160" height="600" border="0" frameborder="0" style="border:none;" scrolling="no"></iframe>
</div><font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Introduction</b></big></font><br />
<br />
In this tutorial you will find out about the .htaccess file and the power it has to improve your website. Although .htaccess is only a file, it can change settings on the servers and allow you to do many different things, the most popular being able to have your own custom 404 error pages. .htaccess isn&#039;t difficult to use and is really just made up of a few simple instructions in a text file.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Will My Host Support It?</b></big></font><br />
<br />
This is probably the hardest question to give a simple answer to. Many hosts support .htaccess but don&#039;t actually publicise it and many other hosts have the capability but do not allow their users to have a .htaccess file. As a general rule, if your server runs Unix or Linux, or any version of the Apache web server it will support .htaccess, although your host may not allow you to use it.<br />
<br />
A good sign of whether your host allows .htaccess files is if they support password protection of folders. To do this they will need to offer .htaccess (although in a few cases they will offer password protection but not let you use .htaccess). The best thing to do if you are unsure is to either upload your own .htaccess file and see if it works or e-mail your web host and ask them.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>What Can I Do?</b></big></font><br />
<br />
You may be wondering what .htaccess can do, or you may have read about some of its uses but don&#039;t realise how many things you can actually do with it.<br />
<br />
There is a huge range of things .htaccess can do including: password protecting folders, redirecting users automatically, custom error pages, changing your file extensions, banning users with certian IP addresses, only allowing users with certain IP addresses, stopping directory listings and using a different file as the index file.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Creating A .htaccess File</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Creating a .htaccess file may cause you a few problems. Writing the file is easy, you just need enter the appropriate code into a text editor (like notepad). You may run into problems with saving the file. Because .htaccess is a strange file name (the file actually has no name but a 8 letter file extension) it may not be accepted on certain systems (e.g. Windows 3.1). With most operating systems, though, all you need to do is to save the file by entering the name as:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&quot;.htaccess&quot;<br />
</font><br />
(including the quotes). If this doesn&#039;t work, you will need to name it something else (e.g. htaccess.txt) and then upload it to the server. Once you have uploaded the file you can then rename it using an FTP program.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Warning</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Before beginning using .htaccess, I should give you one warning. Although using .htaccess on your server is extremely unlikely to cause you any problems (if something is wrong it simply won&#039;t work), you should be wary if you are using the Microsoft FrontPage Extensions. The FrontPage extensions use the .htaccess file so you should not really edit it to add your own information. If you do want to (this is not recommended, but possible) you should download the .htaccess file from your server first (if it exists) and then add your code to the beginning.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Custom Error Pages</b></big></font><br />
<br />
The first use of the .htaccess file which I will cover is custom error pages. These will allow you to have your own, personal error pages (for example when a file is not found) instead of using your host&#039;s error pages or having no page. This will make your site seem much more professional in the unlikely event of an error. It will also allow you to create scripts to notify you if there is an error (for example I use a PHP script on Free Webmaster Help to automatically e-mail me when a page is not found).<br />
<br />
You can use custom error pages for any error as long as you know its number (like 404 for page not found) by adding the following to your .htaccess file:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
ErrorDocument errornumber /file.html<br />
</font><br />
For example if I had the file notfound.html in the root direct<br />
ory of my site and I wanted to use it for a 404 error I would use:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
ErrorDocument 404 /notfound.html<br />
</font><br />
If the file is not in the root directory of your site, you just need to put the path to it:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
ErrorDocument 500 /errorpages/500.html<br />
</font><br />
These are some of the most common errors:<br />
<br />
401 - Authorization Required<br />
400 - Bad request<br />
403 - Forbidden<br />
500 - Internal Server Error<br />
404 - Wrong page<br />
<br />
Then, all you need to do is to create a file to display when the error happens and upload it and the .htaccess file.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Part 2</b></big></font><br />
<br />
In part 2 I will show you how to use some of the other .htaccess functions to improve your website.</font></p>

              <!-- Bottom Navigation -->
              <table width="100%" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2" border="0">
              <tr>
              
              
              
              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><b>Part 1 - Introduction</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/htaccess/2">Part 2 - .htaccess Commands</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/htaccess/3">Part 3 - Password Protection</a></li></ul></font></p></td>
              
              <!-- Related Links -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top">
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul>
                   <li><a href="http://www.kxs.net/support/htaccess_pw.html">KxS Password Encrypter</a></li><li><a href="http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/howto/htaccess.html">Apache .htaccess Documentation</a></li><li><a href="http://www.meteorsurf.com/cgi-bin/smartsearch/smartsearch.cgi?username=gowansnet&keywords=htaccess">More .htaccess Sites</a></li><li><a href="#amazonlinks">Related Reading</a></li>
</ul></font>
</td>

			 <!-- End Bottom Navigation -->
			 </tr></table>

             </td><td width="9">&nbsp;</td>
        </tr>
      </table>
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
